awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Rhesus macaque canine dimorphism in evolutionary context
awd_abstract_narration:
In many primate species, males have much larger canines than do females, a character known as canine sexual dimorphism. In humans, the canines of males and females are very similar in size (monomorphic). This doctoral research project investigates the evolution and function of large male canine teeth in a model primate species to better understand potential selection pressures for dimorphism, and to use as comparative data to understand why the loss of this feature evolved in humans. This project provides training opportunities in both fieldwork and data analysis for undergraduate and graduate students in New York and Puerto Rico. 

This study will integrate morphological, genetic, and behavioral data to test the hypothesis that large male canines are a sexually selected signal and/or weapon in primates. This project also explores mechanisms of canine size evolution (heritability and selection). The Co-PI will collect data on canine size to investigate how canine size is inherited and whether canine size predicts reproductive success. She will also conduct field experiments to determine if males and females attend to differences in male canine size. Finally, she will integrate canine size data with behavioral data to assess whether canine size predicts the occurrence and outcome of fights between males. The results of this project will contribute knowledge about the mechanisms behind both the evolution of canine dimorphism and the loss of this character in humans.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Many non-human primate species display sexual dimorphism (differences between males and females) in body mass and canine tooth size. Modern humans, however, have monomorphic canines (the canine teeth in biological males and females are similar in size) and reduced body mass dimorphism, compared to our closest living relatives, non-human primates. Canine monomorphism is one of the few unique skeletal traits of our species. To date, we know little about the function of sexual dimorphism in body mass and canine size in non-human primates. Theory predicts that large male size relative to female size has evolved in response to male-male mating competition, and that large size enables males to be more effective at competing for mating opportunities through fights with other males. However, empirical evidence to support this prediction is limited. This project investigated how and why sexual dimorphism in these traits is maintained in a moderately sexually dimorphic non-human primate species, the rhesus macaque, in order to better understand why sexual dimorphism in these traits may have been lost in modern humans. Specifically, the project tested whether canine teeth and large body size function as signals and/or weapons, and whether larger males produce more offspring. 

 

Intellectual Merit 

This project generated new data, and extended the use of previously collected data, on the function of sexually dimorphic traits in non-human primates. The co-PI collected new experimental data on attention to images of yawning male rhesus macaques, a facial expression in which upper canine teeth are visible. The co-PI also collected data on body mass and canine height in rhesus macaques, contributing to long-term morphometric datasets.  Results from the project revealed no evidence that large canine teeth and large size assist males in winning competitive interactions with other males, and no evidence that larger males produced more offspring. These results build upon prior findings from highly sexually dimorphic species, which show that weaponized traits influence competitive interactions and reproductive output. Findings from the project challenge previously held assumptions about the function of large body size and weaponized traits in male mammals, and data generated in this project will contribute to knowledge on, and comparisons of, sexually dimorphic traits across primate species and beyond.   

 

Broader Impacts 

This project provided training and outreach opportunities for trainees at a range of levels. The award supported a graduate student completing a PhD thesis. The graduate student developed skills in data collection, management, and analysis, as well as in scientific writing, interdisciplinary collaboration, and personnel management. An undergraduate student wrote a thesis using data generated by this project. Trainees travelled to Puerto Rico to work at the Cayo Santiago Biological Field Station, which was devastated by hurricane Maria in 2017. Recent undergraduate and masters students supported by the award assisted with field data collection and participated in hurricane recovery programs (beach clean-up, tree planting) in the local community. Results from this project have been disseminated through peer-reviewed publications, presentations at national conferences, and seminars at international universities. The co-PI has also communicated about the project on Twitter and through blog posts.


Last Modified: 07/28/2022
Modified by: Clare Kimock
